content:
Diagnosis:	Gliosarcoma, right frontal lobe, IDH-wildtype, WHO Grade IV
		Extensive leptomeningeal dissemination

Management:	Biopsy of right frontal lobe lesion (2025-01-20): Gliosarcoma, IDH-wildtype, MGMT promoter unmethylated
		No surgical resection feasible due to extensive infiltration

Current Situation:	67-year-old male with newly diagnosed gliosarcoma presenting with cognitive decline, persistent headaches, and left-sided hemiparesis.
		MRI brain (2025-01-15): 6.2cm right frontal enhancing mass with vasogenic edema, midline shift of 9mm, and leptomeningeal enhancement
		CSF cytology (2025-01-25): Positive for malignant cells consistent with gliosarcoma

Medical History:	Hypertension, type 2 diabetes with mild nephropathy, ischemic heart disease (stent in 2018)
		Medications: Amlodipine, metformin, atorvastatin, aspirin, ramipril
		No known drug allergies

Clinical Impression:	This gentlemanâ€™s case is profoundly complex given the aggressive nature of gliosarcoma, widespread disease, and significant baseline comorbidities. He has rapidly progressive symptoms affecting his independence and quality of life. In view of the leptomeningeal involvement and the patient's wishes, the focus will be on palliation and symptom management.

Plan:	Initiate palliative craniospinal radiotherapy (20Gy in 5 fractions) to address symptoms of mass effect
		Commence dexamethasone 8mg twice daily to reduce vasogenic edema
		Levetiracetam 500mg twice daily for seizure prophylaxis
		Arrange hospice care referral for ongoing support
		Regular follow-up with neuro-oncology and palliative care teams
		Repeat MRI in 8 weeks to assess response
